Calculator

Class BusinessLogic

  • java.lang.Object
    • Calculator.BusinessLogic

  • public class BusinessLogic
extends java.lang.Object

    Title: BusinessLogic Class.

    Description: The code responsible for performing the calculator business logic functions. This method deals with CalculatorValues and performs actions on them. The class expects data from the User Interface to arrive as Strings and returns Strings to it. This class calls the CalculatorValue class to do computations and this class knows nothing about the actual representation of CalculatorValues, that is the responsibility of the CalculatorValue class and the classes it calls.

    Copyright: Lynn Robert Carter Â© 2019

    Version:
    4.00 2018-01-24 The JavaFX-based GUI implementation of a long integer calculator, 4.01 2019-01-29 Added the Subtraction, Multiplication and Division method to perform the Calculations., 4.02 2019-02-19 Aman added the Logarithmic method to calculate the log Jatin added the condition to test the different value of the text field., 4.03 2019-03-20 No changes made in this class for this version., 4.04 2019-04-06 Constructor had been changed so that it accept the error term also. Methods have also been changed so that they can accept the error term, 4.05 2019-09-29 Methods and constructors are changed to accept the values of UNumber., 4.06 2019-11-24 Methods are created to make the calculator compatible with Units., 4.07 2020-03-12 Methods are created to make the calculator compatible with definitions and TableView.
    Author:
    Lynn Robert Carter (Baseline), Jatin Thakur

    • Field Detail

      • one

        public static boolean one
        This public method computes the quotient of the two operands using the CalculatorValue class method for division. The goal of this class is to support a wide array of different data representations without requiring a change to this class, user interface class, or the Calculator class. This method assumes the operands are defined and valid. It replaces the left operand with the result of the computation and it leaves an error message, if there is one, in a String variable set aside for that purpose. This method does not take advantage or know any detail of the representation! All of that is hidden from this class by the CalculatorValue class and any other classes that it may use.

      • zero

        public static boolean zero

    • Constructor Detail

      • BusinessLogic

        public BusinessLogic()
        This method initializes all of the elements of the business logic aspect of the calculator. There is no special computational initialization required, so the initialization of the attributes above are all that are needed.

      • setOperand1

        public boolean setOperand1(java.lang.String value,
                           java.lang.String value1)
        This public method takes an input String , checks to see if there is a non-empty input string. If so, it places the converted CalculatorValue into operand1 and error term, any associated error message into operand1ErrorMessage, and sets flags accordingly.
        Parameters:
        value -
        Returns:
        True if the set did not generate an error; False if there was invalid input

        public boolean setOperand2(java.lang.String value,

If so, it places the converted CalculatorValue into operand2 and error term, any associated error message into operand1ErrorMessage, and sets flags accordingly. The logic of this method is the same as that for operand1 above.
        Parameters:
        value -
        Returns:
        True if the set did not generate an error; False if there was invalid input

        public boolean setResult(java.lang.String value,

If so, it places the converted CalculatorValue into result and error term, any associated error message into resuyltErrorMessage, and sets flags accordingly. The logic of this method is similar to that for operand1 above. (There is no defined flag.)
        Parameters:
        value -
        Returns:
        True if the set did not generate an error; False if there was invalid input

      • getOperand1Defined

        public boolean getOperand1Defined()
        This public getter fetches the defined attribute for operand1. You can't use the lack of an error message to know that the operand is ready to be used. An empty operand has no error associated with it, so the class checks to see if it is defined and has no error before setting this flag true.
        Returns:
        true if the operand is defined and has no error, else false

      • getOperand2Defined

        public boolean getOperand2Defined()
        This public getter fetches the defined attribute for operand2. You can't use the lack of an error message to know that the operand is ready to be used. An empty operand has no error associated with it, so the class checks to see if it is defined and has no error before setting this flag true.
        Returns:
        true if the operand is defined and has no error, else false

      • toString

        public java.lang.String toString()
        This toString method invokes the toString method of the result type (CalculatorValue is this case) to convert the value from its hidden internal representation into a String, which can be manipulated directly by the BusinessLogic and the UserInterface classes.
        Overrides:
        toString in class java.lang.Object

      • addition

        public java.lang.String addition()
        This public method computes the sum of the two operands using the CalculatorValue class method for addition. The goal of this class is to support a wide array of different data representations without requiring a change to this class, user interface class, or the Calculator class. This method assumes the operands are defined and valid. It replaces the left operand with the result of the computation and it leaves an error message, if there is one, in a String variable set aside for that purpose. This method does not take advantage or know any detail of the representation! All of that is hidden from this class by the CalculatorValue class and any other classes that it may use.
        Returns:
        a String representation of the result
